title: RC circuits - energy in cap vs supplied by battery

content.question: A circuit contains a battery, an initially open switch, an initially uncharged capacitor, and a resistor, as shown in the figure. The switch is closed at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. After a long time passes the capacitor can be considered to be completely charged. How does the final electric potential energy <math alttext="U sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> stored in the capacitor compare to the energy <math alttext="E sub battery" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>bat</mi></msub></math> transferred out of the battery, and what evidence or reasoning helps to support the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="U sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> is less than <math alttext="E sub battery" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>bat</mi></msub></math>. Power is dissipated in the resistor while the capacitor is charging.

<math alttext="U sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> is less than <math alttext="E sub battery" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>bat</mi></msub></math>. The capacitor charge at time <math alttext="t equals R C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>R</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is less than its final value.

<math alttext="U sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="E sub battery" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>bat</mi></msub></math> are equal. The battery current and the capacitor current are equal at all times.

<math alttext="U sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="E sub battery" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>bat</mi></msub></math> are equal. The final potential difference across the capacitor is equal to the battery <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="U sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> is less than <math alttext="E sub battery" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>bat</mi></msub></math>. Power is dissipated in the resistor while the capacitor is charging.
